newscientist.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website for New Scientist, a magazine publishing reports on science, technology, health, and the environment.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

New Scientist magazine and its website are owned by New Scientist Ltd., a private British company. The site publishes editions in the U.K., the U.S., and Australia.

The site runs advertisements and offers a digital subscription for full access to its online content.

Content

The site publishes articles in categories including news, technology, space, physics, health, earth, humans, and life. Most articles focus on news and innovation related to technology, such as an article about artificial intelligence titled “AI tries bad improv comedy to trick people into thinking it is human.” Other articles cover topics related to health, such as an article about arthritis research titled “An antioxidant might lead to new therapies for bone arthritis.” Some articles cover recent scientific studies, summarizing the findings and possible ramifications or applications of those findings, such as a September 2018 article titled “Gluten may be making you tired and depressed according to a new study.” Newscientist.com also publishes content less scientifically oriented and more focused on culture and history, such as a May 2018 article titled “Nine curious colours that shaped the history of art” or a September 2018 article titled “Iran’s Pompeii: Astounding story of a massacre buried for millennia.”

New Scientist’s staff produces some content specifically for the website. For example, a September 2018 article titled “Why wouldn’t you want to live forever? New Scientist editors debate,” featured the staff’s views on immortality.

Credibility

Newscientist.com is written in objective language and cites sources widely accepted as reliable by the scientific community, including peer reviewed articles, reports, and case studies. 

A NewsGuard review found that the website makes regular corrections, although it does not feature information on how to submit a correction or state a correction policy. The corrections are attached to articles with an explanation of the error, while the content is updated to remove the mistakes. Gavin Power, a customer services manager for the site, told NewsGuard that readers can submit corrections requests by emailing the readers’ editors. He gave an address that is not visible on the site’s Contact Us form.

Transparency

Newscientist.com’s About Us page links to the website for the New Scientist media company. The site’s Who’s Who page features the names of the management, editorial, and production staff at New Scientist. It also details general contact information for those departments. The Contact Us page has a form for readers to submit questions and comments.

Bylines do not link to biographical or contact information for writers. Power told NewsGuard that a separate page titled “Guide for Freelancers” includes the names and linked email addresses of editors across departments.

Sponsored content is marked.

History

New Scientist was first published in 1956 as a weekly print magazine. The newscientist.com domain was registered by New Scientist Ltd. in 1995.
